Message.Title: Windows XP decline stalls as users hold onto aged OS, flaunt 2014 deadline
Message.Msg: W8 sure is an off-putting piece of garbage....... ================================================ A third of all Windows users could still be running XP when Microsoft pulls patch plug in 53 weeks. Computerworld - The decline in usage share of Windows XP, which is slated for retirement in 53 weeks, has slowed significantly, hinting that millions of its users will hold onto the operating system much longer than some, including Microsoft, expect. Data published monthly by California-based Web analytics company Net Applications indicates that XP's long-running slide has virtually stalled since Jan. 1. In the past three months, Windows XP's monthly drop in share has averaged just 0.12 of a percentage point. That's less than a fifth as much as the 12-month average of 0.68 percentage points. ===============================================

Topic.Title: Show Me an American Ghetto

Message.Msg: Well you ask some decent but easily answered questions. The low skilled working population has tripled roughly in the last 50 years which has driven wages into the ground. There is no boundless opportunity for ALL Americans. It is emotionally driven type one thinking that ALL can win or even place in the race. There will always be a bottom no matter what. It is a grand idea to help people learn how to "do" and provide motivation for them to "do" but not at the expense of throwing some people to the wolves. Gratitude for what ???

Message.Title: two silly emotionally driven position with respect to public assistance
Message.Msg: 1 That everybody deserves certain things for free if they cannot buy them. The actual rule is that those who cannot earn basic necessities are entitled to them if the society can afford it without self imploding, ( high earners will still have to pay the tax even if they btch and moan all day every day as long as possible) 2 That everybody can "achieve" this level of necessity regardless of the economy situation. The actual state is that there will frequently be situations in which the bottom performers cannot earn enough to make it and the bottom cannot be 'motivated' or 'trained' to NOT be at the bottom and will require social help, and any reasonable society provides this. In fact all developed societies do. The rub of course is in the eternal war between the wealthy who want poor and desperate workers and the group who wants to sit back and coast on their arz.

Message.Title: Intel investors face CEO hiring, PC slowdown concerns
Message.Msg: Google it... Quoting: ' "We believe lower PC growth is becoming more systemic," Chin wrote. UBS expects PC unit sales to decline by 4.5% in 2013 and 0.9% in 2014. "We expect consumers to continue to prefer smartphones/tablets to PCs for many computing tasks, resulting in a combination of PC replacement cycle elongation and cannibalization." 'Many consumers have made a behavioral shift away from PCs, exacerbated by the more complex user interface of Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows 8, Chin said. 'Intel has missed out on the growth of smartphones and tablets because hardware vendors have preferred chips designed by rival ARM Holdings (ARMH). On the plus side, Intel's chips for servers and data centers have remained in high demand.

Message.Title: Arkansas Oil Spill Raises Scrutiny of Pipeline Network
Message.Msg: Arkansas Oil Spill Raises Scrutiny of Pipeline Network Bloomberg By Jim Snyder & Bradley Olson - Apr 1, 2013 11:00 PM CT An oil spill that fouled an Arkansas town is raising questions about the U.S. pipeline network and the safety of importing Canadian heavy crude, as President Barack Obama weighs whether to approve the Keystone XL project. . Environmental groups said the rupture of the Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) pipe on March 29 in Mayflower, Arkansas, shows why Obama should reject Keystone, which would be a major new conduit between the U.S. and Canada for a type of fuel critics say is more corrosive than more conventional forms of oil. “Without question, this underscores the risks of transporting this stuff,” Jim Murphy, senior counsel at the National Wildlife Federation, said yesterday in a phone interview. The U.S. State Department is reviewing TransCanada Corp.’s (TRP) Keystone project to link Alberta’s oil sands with refineries along the Gulf Coast because it crosses an international border. White House press secretary Jay Carney said yesterday the White House takes the safety of the pipeline system “very seriously.” He said the Environmental Protection Agency is working with local officials and Exxon on the Arkansas spill.
